answer_html: Hence, the eigenvalues \(\displaystyle \lambda_{1,2}\) are \(\displaystyle -1 + 2i\) and \(\displaystyle -1 - 2i\).
hints_html:
Find the eigenvalues of the matrix

\(A = \begin{pmatrix} -1 & -2 \\ 2 & -1\end{pmatrix}\).

The eigenvalues of \(\displaystyle A\) are calculated by

\(\text{det}(A-\lambda I) = \text{det}\begin{pmatrix}-1-\lambda & -2 \\ 2 & -1-\lambda\end{pmatrix}\)

and find \(\displaystyle \lambda\).
hints_latex:
Find the eigenvalues of the matrix

$A = \begin{pmatrix} -1 & -2 \\ 2 & -1\end{pmatrix}$.

The eigenvalues of $\displaystyle A$ are calculated by

$\text{det}(A-\lambda I) = \text{det}\begin{pmatrix}-1-\lambda & -2 \\ 2 & -1-\lambda\end{pmatrix}$

and find $\displaystyle \lambda$.
hints_raw:
Find the eigenvalues of the matrix

<math> A = \begin{pmatrix} -1 & -2 \\ 2 & -1\end{pmatrix} </math>.
The eigenvalues of <math>\displaystyle A </math> are calculated by

<math> \text{det}(A-\lambda I) = \text{det}\begin{pmatrix}-1-\lambda & -2 \\ 2 & -1-\lambda\end{pmatrix} </math>

and find <math>\displaystyle \lambda </math>.
question: 8 (a)
sols_html:
To calculate the eigenvalues of the matrix \(A = \begin{pmatrix} -1 & -2 \\ 2 & -1\end{pmatrix}\), we find \(\displaystyle \lambda\) such that

\[\begin{aligned} 0 &= \text{det}\begin{pmatrix}-1-\lambda & -2 \\ 2 & -1-\lambda\end{pmatrix}\\ &= (-1-\lambda)^2 + 4\\ &= \lambda^2 + 2\lambda + 5\end{aligned}\]

To calculate \(\displaystyle \lambda\), we use the quadratic formula,

\(\lambda_{1,2} = \frac{-2\pm\sqrt{4-20}}{2} = -1\pm2i\)

where \(\displaystyle \sqrt{-1} = i\).

Hence, the eigenvalues \(\displaystyle \lambda_{1,2}\) are \(\displaystyle -1 + 2i\) and \(\displaystyle -1 - 2i\).
sols_latex:
To calculate the eigenvalues of the matrix
$A = \begin{pmatrix} -1 & -2 \\ 2 & -1\end{pmatrix}$, we find
$\displaystyle \lambda$ such that

\begin{align*}
0 &= \text{det}\begin{pmatrix}-1-\lambda & -2 \\ 2 & -1-\lambda\end{pmatrix}\\
  &= (-1-\lambda)^2 + 4\\
  &= \lambda^2 + 2\lambda + 5
\end{align*}

To calculate $\displaystyle \lambda$, we use the quadratic formula,

$\lambda_{1,2} = \frac{-2\pm\sqrt{4-20}}{2} = -1\pm2i$

where $\displaystyle \sqrt{-1} = i$.

Hence, the eigenvalues $\displaystyle \lambda_{1,2}$ are
$\displaystyle -1 + 2i$ and $\displaystyle -1 - 2i$.
sols_raw:
To calculate the eigenvalues of the matrix <math> A = \begin{pmatrix} -1 & -2 \\ 2 & -1\end{pmatrix} </math>, we find <math>\displaystyle \lambda </math>  such that
 
<math> 
\begin{align}
0 & = \text{det}\begin{pmatrix}-1-\lambda & -2 \\ 2 & -1-\lambda\end{pmatrix}\\
  & = (-1-\lambda)^2 + 4\\
  & = \lambda^2 + 2\lambda + 5
\end{align}
</math>

To calculate <math> \displaystyle \lambda </math>, we use the quadratic formula,

<math> \lambda_{1,2} = \frac{-2\pm\sqrt{4-20}}{2} = -1\pm2i </math>

where <math>\displaystyle \sqrt{-1} = i</math>.

Hence, the eigenvalues <math>\displaystyle \lambda_{1,2} </math> are <math>\displaystyle -1 + 2i</math> and <math>\displaystyle -1 - 2i</math>.
statement_html:
Consider the 2 x 2 system of differential equations

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{x}'(t)=\begin{bmatrix} -1 & -2\\ 2 & -1 \end{bmatrix} \mathbf{x}(t)\end{aligned}\]

where \(\mathbf{x}(t)=\begin{bmatrix}x_1(t)\\x_2(t)\end{bmatrix}\) is the vector of unknown functions.

Find all eigenvalues that may or may not be complex valued.
statement_raw:
Consider the 2 x 2 system of differential equations

:<math>
\mathbf{x}'(t)=\begin{bmatrix}
-1  &  -2\\
2  &  -1
\end{bmatrix} \mathbf{x}(t)
</math>

where <math>\mathbf{x}(t)=\begin{bmatrix}x_1(t)\\x_2(t)\end{bmatrix}</math> is the vector of unknown functions.

Find all eigenvalues that may or may not be complex valued.
